docs.title: Welcome to ASIC Interview Questions! 🚀
📌 About This Website
docs.text:
This website is a collection of ASIC design interview questions, covering: - Digital Design - Verification - Physical Design - Synthesis & STA - DFT (Design for Test) - Mixed-Signal Design - Low-Power Design

Whether you're preparing for an ASIC Engineer role or brushing up on key concepts, this site will help!

docs.title: 🔍 How to Use This Site
docs.text:
• Navigate using the top menu or search bar.
  • Click on a topic to explore interview questions and answers.

Powered by MkDocs & Material for MkDocs.

docs.title: DFT (Design for Test) Interview Questions
1. What is scan chain in DFT?
docs.text: A scan chain converts flip-flops into shift registers, allowing test patterns to be shifted in and out.

docs.title: 2. What is stuck-at fault testing?
docs.text: A stuck-at-0 or stuck-at-1 fault occurs when a signal remains at a fixed value, regardless of input.

docs.title: 3. What is ATPG?
docs.text: Automatic Test Pattern Generation (ATPG) generates test patterns to detect faults in ASICs.

docs.title: 4. What is BIST (Built-In Self-Test)?
docs.text: BIST is a self-checking circuit that runs internal tests without external test vectors.

docs.title: 5. What is boundary scan (JTAG)?
docs.text: JTAG (IEEE 1149.1) allows testing of I/O pins without physical probes.

docs.title: Digital Design Interview Questions
1. What is setup and hold time?
docs.text: Setup time is the minimum time before the clock edge that data must be stable. Hold time is the minimum time after the clock edge that data must remain stable.

docs.title: 2. What happens if setup time is violated?
docs.text: A setup time violation can cause metastability, leading to unpredictable output states.

docs.title: 3. How does a flip-flop differ from a latch?
docs.text: Feature Flip-Flop (FF) Latch Triggered by Clock edge Level-sensitive Power Consumption Higher Lower Usage Registers, Pipelines Gating, Low-power designs

docs.title: 4. How do you synchronize an asynchronous signal in a clocked system?
docs.text: A 2-flop synchronizer is used to avoid metastability when transferring signals across clock domains.

docs.title: 5. What is meant by "glitch" in combinational logic?
docs.text: A glitch is a temporary unintended pulse due to differing propagation delays in logic paths.

docs.title: Mixed-Signal Design Interview Questions
1. What are the key challenges in mixed-signal verification?
docs.text:
• Analog-digital interface modeling
  • Noise coupling effects
  • Cross-domain synchronization

docs.title: 2. How does an ADC work?
docs.text: An Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) samples an analog signal and converts it into a digital word using quantization.

docs.title: 3. What are common ADC architectures?
docs.text:
• SAR ADC (Successive Approximation Register)
  • Pipeline ADC
  • Sigma-Delta ADC

docs.title: 4. What is phase noise in PLLs?
docs.text: Phase noise is the jitter in frequency output of a PLL caused by noise sources.

docs.title: 5. What is charge pump leakage?
docs.text: Leakage in charge pumps causes voltage drift, affecting PLL stability.

docs.title: Physical Design (PD) Interview Questions
1. What are the key steps in ASIC Physical Design?
docs.text:
• Floorplanning
  • Power Planning
  • Placement & CTS (Clock Tree Synthesis)
  • Routing
  • Timing Closure & Signoff

docs.title: 2. What is clock skew and how is it managed?
docs.text: Clock skew is the difference in clock arrival times at different flip-flops. Managed using: - Clock Tree Synthesis (CTS) - Buffering and Load Balancing - Useful Skew Adjustment

docs.title: 3. What is OCV (On-Chip Variation) and why does it matter?
docs.text: OCV accounts for process variations across the die, affecting timing closure.

docs.title: 4. What is IR Drop and how is it reduced?
docs.text: IR Drop is voltage loss due to resistance in power rails. Reduced by: - Adding Power Straps - Using Proper Decap Cells - Optimizing Routing Layers

docs.title: Synthesis & Static Timing Analysis (STA) Interview Questions
1. What is the difference between RTL and netlist?
docs.text:
• RTL is high-level, written in Verilog/VHDL.
  • Netlist is a gate-level representation after synthesis.

docs.title: 2. What are false paths and multi-cycle paths?
docs.text:
• False Path: A timing path that never gets activated in real operation.
  • Multi-Cycle Path (MCP): A path that has more than one clock cycle to complete.

docs.title: 3. What are setup and hold time violations?
docs.text:
• Setup Violation: Data is not stable before the clock edge.
  • Hold Violation: Data changes too early after the clock edge.

docs.title: 4. What is clock gating and why is it used?
docs.text: Clock gating reduces dynamic power consumption by disabling the clock when logic is inactive.

docs.title: 5. What is the role of PrimeTime in ASIC design?
docs.text: PrimeTime (PT) is a timing analysis tool used for: - Setup/Hold Analysis - Clock Tree Analysis - Path Delay Debugging

docs.title: ASIC Verification Interview Questions
1. What is constrained random verification?
docs.text: Constrained random verification (CRV) is a UVM methodology where input vectors are randomly generated under constraints to improve test coverage.

docs.title: 2. What is functional coverage, and how is it different from code coverage?
docs.text:
• Functional coverage ensures that all features and scenarios are tested.
  • Code coverage checks if all statements, branches, and FSM states in RTL were exercised.

docs.title: 3. What are assertions in verification?
docs.text: Assertions are properties written in SVA (SystemVerilog Assertions) to monitor and validate signal behavior during simulation.

docs.title: 4. What is a transaction in UVM?
docs.text: A transaction is a data object that captures signal transfers, representing a single event in stimulus-response modeling.

docs.title: 5. How do you debug a failing test in simulation?
docs.text:
1. Check waveform (VCD, FSDB)
  2. Analyze log files for assertion failures
  3. Use UVM debug tools (uvm_report, backtrace)
  4. Enable finer-grained print logs
